attributes.title: Sentencing Goals Inventory - Public Perception of Releasing Prisoners Due to Covid-19
attributes.description: The emergence of Covid-19 as a worldwide pandemic has caused several questions to arise in all aspects of living in the United States. One such question revolves around how to handle incarcerated individuals with arguments being made to release certain offenders to reduce the spread and mortality rate of the virus. This study examines the underlying motivations behind why people want to punish and the attributions they make to criminal activity and relates these two concepts to attitudes people have on releasing criminal offenders during the nationwide pandemic.

q2.value: 1) The level of consideration given toward criminal-offender well being during a time of crisis will be predicted by the attributions to crime and motivations behind punishment.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study will use a survey design with several measures that are meant to gather information on people's views of criminal offenders.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data will be collected from Prolific academic using their nationally representative U.S. sample. Participants must be 18 and from the U.S. to be included in the sample. Participants will be excluded if they do not answer the measures fully.

q12.value: We will collect data until we run out of money.

question.value:
The Sentencing Goals Inventory 
- Utilitarian 
- Retribution  
- Rehabilitation  

Caroll Criminal Attributions Scale

- Social causation
- Economic causation
- Individual causation 

Consideration for Offenders (7 item measure with questions relating to attitudes people have toward releasing offenders to reduce the spread of Covid-19)

Hierarchical Regression 

Consideration toward Offenders ~ 

Step 1: (Demographic info relating to  experience with incarcerated individuals + income level) 
Step 2: (Carroll economic + Carroll Social + Carroll Individual) 
Step 3: (SGI Scales)

q21.value: If participants do not have full response sets (no items missing) they will be excluded.

attributes.title: The role of overconfidence in the escalation of commitment to failing drug development projects
attributes.description: The purpose of this project will be to explore two distinct sources of overconfidence (biased ability and biased probability) as well as the role of responsibility in drug development decision making.

q2.value:
H1: Overconfidence from biased ability will increase the escalation of commitment to a drug development project despite negative feedback. 
H2: Overconfidence from biased probability will increase the escalation of commitment to a drug development project despite negative feedback. 
H3: Felt responsibility will increase the escalation of commitment to a drug development project despite negative feedback. 
H4: Risk perception will partially mediate the effects of overconfidence and felt responsibility on escalation of commitment.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: The study design is a 3 (overconfidence: biased ability, biased probability, control) x 2 (responsibility: high, low) between-subjects design.

q7.value: This study will use simple randomization provided by the software that we will use to administer the experiment (Qualtrics)

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will collect data from two populations: student and expert.
For the student population, we will include graduate (masters, doctoral) students in the life sciences who have at least four years’ education and relevant training in drug development.
The expert population will consist of life sciences professionals with a minimum of one year’s professional experience in drug development.

q12.value: We used G*Power to compute a power analysis based on reported effect sizes in the literature. The variable with the lowest effect size was overconfidence (r = 0.219) (Sleesman, Conlon, McNamara & Miles, 2012), so we used that value for our analysis. Based on the design of our experiment, the number of variables and the effect size, we would need 323 participants to reach a statistical power of 0.95.

question.value:
We will manipulate overconfidence by creating three groups - biased ability, biased probability and control.
We will manipulate responsibility by creating two groups - high responsibility and low responsibility.

We will measure risk perception, which will be used as a mediator.
We will measure escalation of commitment, which is our outcome variable.

For the main analysis, we will use a 3x2 between subjects ANOVA with overconfidence and responsibility as the two factors. We will test for the main effects of these factors, as well as the interaction between them. 

We also have manipulation checks in the form of simple Likert scale questions. These questions will be presented after the introduction of the main task before participants see the executive reports.
To ensure that our overconfidence materials did in fact increase participant’s confidence in their abilities, we will present them with the following question:
How confident are you about making the correct decisions for this drug to reach the market? (from 1 = ‘Not confident’ to 7 = ‘Very confident’)
To make sure that the information we present about their role in the project (initiator or consultant) affects their felt responsibility towards it, we will ask the following question after they have read the introduction to the main task but before they see the executive reports. 
How responsible do you feel for the outcome of this project? (from 1 = ‘Not responsible’ to 7 = ‘Very responsible’)
Any further main analyses will be contingent on satisfactory results from the manipulation checks stated above. Since these checks are implemented to assess whether our independent variables had the expected effect on the constructs they were targeting, we propose that they should all be significant at the p < .05 values. Any independent variables that fail to pass the manipulation checks will not be included in the main analyses. The overconfidence manipulation will be analysed using a one-way ANOVA with planned contrasts, and the responsibility manipulation will be analysed using a t-test for differences in means.

q19.value: We will use the standard P<.05 criteria for inference from the main analyses.

q21.value: Missing and incomplete data will not be included in the analysis.

registration_responses.q2:
H1: Overconfidence from biased ability will increase the escalation of commitment to a drug development project despite negative feedback. 
H2: Overconfidence from biased probability will increase the escalation of commitment to a drug development project despite negative feedback. 
H3: Felt responsibility will increase the escalation of commitment to a drug development project despite negative feedback. 
H4: Risk perception will partially mediate the effects of overconfidence and felt responsibility on escalation of commitment.

attributes.title: Brilliant Thinkers, Empathic Therapists: What Explains the Gender Gap in Philosophy versus Psychology?
attributes.description: The underrepresentation of women in the academy is not limited to STEM-fields, but instead generalizes to most fields that emphasize high intellectual ability. Despite the overlap in subject matter between psychology and philosophy, there is a marked gender imbalance across the two fields. There are many fewer women in philosophy and many fewer men in psychology. The purpose of the current study is to pilot self-report scales that allow for tests of hypothesized explanations for the gender imbalances across these two fields.  We will measure stereotypical beliefs about gender and brilliance, internal beliefs about abilities, gender differences in interest and combativeness, beliefs and preferences regarding work-life balance, and beliefs about the status of each field as regards these features.

q1.value: Heather M. Maranges, Katharina Nieswandt, Kristen Dunfield, Ulf Hlobil, Maxine Iannuccilli

q2.value:
1)	In this pilot survey study, we expect that items of each a priori scale will load onto single factors (or a primary factor and reverse coded “artifactor” for scales with many reverse coded items) in exploratory factor analyses of each scale. See variable section for a priori scales.

We will also provide a tentative test of the following hypotheses, which have been forwarded as explanations for the gender imbalances across philosophy and psychology.

The Brilliance explanation is that philosophy, but not psychology, is viewed as requiring brilliance and that both men and women believe men have more innate brilliance than women. 

2)	Philosophy will be viewed as requiring more innate brilliance than psychology.
3)	Men will view themselves as having more innate brilliance than women.
4)	Women will hold stronger fixed (vs. growth) mindset beliefs compared to men.

The Combativeness explanation is that philosophy is compatible with or requires argumentativeness and men tend to be more argumentative than women. 

5)	Philosophy will be viewed as benefiting from a combative (vs. cooperative) nature, more than psychology.
6)	Men will view themselves as more combative (vs. cooperative) than women.

The Interest explanation is that women are more interested in people versus things—or are more empathizing versus systematizing—and vice versa, and psychology provides opportunities to empathize whereas philosophy provides opportunities to systematize.

7)	Men will view themselves as more systematizing (vs. empathizing), compared to women.

The Status vs. Family-Focus explanation is that women versus men value having a career that allows for having flexibility and a family and men value a career that garners social status; that psychology, versus philosophy, allows for flexibility for a family; and philosophy, versus psychology, garners social status. 

8)	Women will score higher on prioritization of a career that allows for a family, compared to men.
9)	Psychology will be viewed as better allowing for a family, compared to philosophy.
10)	Men will score higher on prioritization of a career that allows for social status, compared to women.
11)	Philosophy, compared to psychology, will be viewed as garnering more social status for women versus men.

We will also explore how desire for monetary wealth is associated with gender and perceptions of philosophy versus psychology. We tentatively expect no differences on average, but that preference for monetary wealth may lead to career choices outside of psychology and philosophy.

12)	Do men versus women prioritize monetary wealth from a career more?
13)	Do people perceive psychology versus philosophy as providing monetary wealth?
14)	Prioritization of monetary wealth from a career may be associated with preference for a career other than in philosophy, and perhaps other than psychology.

Finally,

15)	Factors for which there is a gender difference will predict academic major choice differences.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Survey, not randomized.
The only experimental aspect is to test whether people rate men and women’s attractiveness differentially depending on their field of study. Participants read a vignette about a recent college graduate, who is a man or woman, studied philosophy or psychology, and is brilliant or empathetic. Hence, this is a 2 (gender) x 2 (field) x 2 (characteristics) design.

q7.value: Randomization. Participants are randomly assigned to one of the 8 vignette conditions, but all participants respond to the same survey.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q9.value: We have begun data collection but have not viewed data.

question.value: Participants will be students in psychology and philosophy classes at two large universities in Montreal, Quebec, CA and Tallahassee, Florida, USA completing an online survey. Psychology students will be compensated with credit toward introductory classes. Participants must be at least 18 years of age.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 350 participants. There will be 150 signup opportunities posted to the American university’s psychology department subject pool sign up system, to which all students in psychology classes have access. 350 students in philosophy and psychology at the Canadian university will be provided with the link to the online survey via class announcement online. Students have until April 15th to complete the survey.

q12.value: Based on prior exploratory piloting pretest data, we expect strong factor loadings on each of our a priori scales such that a minimum of 300 participants should allow us to establish a reliable factor structure via factor analyses (for review, see Kyriazos, 2018

q13.value: Data collection will be complete by April 15th at 5:00PM/17:00.

question.value:
The only experimental aspect is to test whether people rate men and women’s attractiveness differentially depending on their field of study. Participants read a vignette about a recent college graduate, who is a man or woman, studied philosophy or psychology, and is brilliant or empathetic. Hence, this is a 2 (gender) x 2 (field) x 2 (characteristics) design.

See vignette attachment.

data.name: Perceptions of attractiveness_Phil vs. Psych_Vignettes A-H.docx

extra.selectedFileName: Perceptions of attractiveness_Phil vs. Psych_Vignettes A-H.docx

question.value:
See questionnaire document.
●	Age
●	Gender identity
●	Race/ethnicity
●	Family income
●	Major
●	Second major
●	Minor
●	Year of study
●	Grade point average upon admission to university
●	Expected grade in course
●	Psychologist stereotype
●	Philosopher stereotype
●	Questionnaire about self measuring: (see below for details on indices)
●	Questionnaire about psychology and philosophy measuring: (see below for details on indices)
●	Attractiveness rating of hypothetical target
●	Ranking of philosophical disciplines for personal interest
●	Ranking of psychological disciplines for personal interest

________Views of the self and fields________

______Brilliance, philosophy______
 If you want to succeed in philosophy, hard work alone just won’t cut it; you need to have an innate gift or talent.
Personally, I think that being a top scholar of philosophy requires a special aptitude that just can’t be taught.
I think that when it comes to philosophy, the most important factors for success are motivation and sustained effort; raw ability is secondary.
I think that with the right amount of effort and dedication, many people could become a top scholar in philosophy. It’s mainly about hard work.
It seems that people are just either good or bad at philosophy and there is not much that they can do to change that.

______Brilliance, psychology______
It seems that people are just either good or bad at psychology, and there is not much that they can do to change that.
I think that when it comes to psychology, the most important factors for success are motivation and sustained effort; raw ability is secondary.
Personally, I think that being a top scholar of psychology requires a special aptitude that just can’t be taught.
If you want to succeed in psychology, hard work alone just won’t cut it; you need to have an innate gift or talent.
 I think that with the right amount of effort and dedication, many people could become a top scholar in psychology. It’s mainly about hard work.

______Brilliance, self______
 I might have a world changing idea at some point.
People around me suspected from early on that I am intellectually gifted.
I tend to take longer to understand complicated ideas and theories than others.
I often have ideas that others didn’t think about.
I would say I am more intellectually gifted than average.
I pick up new concepts much faster than many classmates.
I need to study much harder than others in order to get good grades.
 I am good at coming up with ideas, and perhaps one day I will have an idea that changes the world.
Although I have never been properly tested, it seems likely that I have an higher than average IQ.
I noticed early on that my mind seems to work less efficiently than the minds of others.

______Combativeness______
I am not bothered by confrontational situations.
I thrive off heated discussions and debates.
I often get passionate in discussions.
If I know I’m right, then I will argue my point until others agree that I am right.
 In group discussions, I don’t like to draw attention to myself.
If a debate or a theoretical discussion gets heated, I feel uncomfortable.
In defending my ideas, I am sometimes perceived as insensitive.
I like to work in a team with others rather than compete with them.
I challenge an idea only if this does not create conflict.
I tend to avoid confrontation.

______Empathizing______
I am good at predicting how someone will feel.
I can tune into how someone else feels.
I can see myself in a job where I care for others, such as social worker or teacher.
I find it easy to put myself in somebody else’s shoes.
I prefer working on my own.
I often find social relations stressful.
I enjoy tasks where I help other people.

______Prioritizing family flexibility vs. interesting career______
Having work/a career that is interesting is my most important life goal, even above having a family.
I expect my family to give me more real satisfaction than anything else I do, including my work/career.
Having and raising children is not one of my life goals.

______Fixed vs. growth mindset______
Your intelligence is something about you that you can’t change very much.
To be honest, you can’t really change how much talent you have.
You can learn new things, but you can’t really change your basic intelligence.
No matter who you are, you can significantly change your intelligence level.
Your talent in an area is something about you that you can’t change very much.
You have a certain amount of intelligence, and you really can’t do much to change it.
You can change even your basic intelligence level considerably.
The harder you work at something, the better you will be.
No matter how much intelligence you have, you can always change it quite a bit.
You can always substantially change how intelligent you are.

______Prioritizing wealth from career______
I want to make a lot of money in my career.
I want a career that will allow me to afford to buy a nice house and other luxury items.
Making enough money to be “well off” is not important to me.

______Prioritizing social status from career______
I want a career that gets respect and admiration.
It is important to me to have a career that provides me with social status.
Building a name and reputation for myself through work/a career is not one of my life goals.

______Systematizing______
I don’t see the point of abstract ideas that don’t help anyone in the real world.
I like to think about abstract ideas.
I am more interested in theories than in working with people.
I am more interested in theories than in applications.
I’d prefer a job where I deal with technology to a job where I deal with human beings.
I am interested in the history of ideas.
I am not really interested in understanding how something works.
Logic puzzles keep me thinking until I find a solution.
I love to learn new abstract ideas.


________Dichotomous choice between philosophy and psychology________

______Brilliance______
If you want to succeed in ______, hard work alone just won’t cut it; you need to have an innate gift or talent.
I think that with the right amount of effort and dedication, many people could become a top scholar in ______. It’s mainly about hard work.
Personally, I think that being a top scholar of ______ requires a special aptitude that just can’t be taught.
I think that when it comes to ______, the most important factors for success are motivation and sustained effort; raw ability is secondary.
It seems that people are just either good or bad at ______ and there is not much they can do to change that.

______Prioritization of family flexibility vs. interesting career______
I think that a job in ______ would allow for flexible work hours.
Working  in ______ would provide an interesting/exciting career.
A career in ____ facilitates the work-life balance essential for having a family.
Working in ______ is well-suited for someone who views raising kids as the most important part of life.
A career in ______ is well-suited for people who want satisfaction from work but nothing else.

______Prioritization of wealth from career______
Working in  ______  would allow someone to buy a nice house and other luxury items.
_____ is well-suited to those who want to make a lot of money in their career.
Making enough money to be “well off” is not a likely result of a career in  ______ .

______Prioritization of social status from career______
Working in ______ would allow a person to build a name and reputation for him/herself.
A career in ______ gets respect and admiration.
Working in ______ provides social status.
If you say that you study ______, people will probably make fun of you.
Sometimes people say that they are interested in ______ to appear smart.
When I meet new people, I think I might be judged negatively if I say I study ______.

First, we will create our indices, test their reliability, and subject them to factor analyses. For the factor analyses, exploratory factor analyses using oblimin/oblique rotation with minimum eigenvalues of 2 will be conducted on a priori scale items. Items that do not load above .5 on or correlate above .4 with the primary factor (or a second reverse coded ‘artifactor’; see ) will be dropped, unless included in an original scale which we have adopted. We will adapt the measures for future use if after factor analyses, the scale alphas are below .75.
Second, we will examine the correlations among the indices, gender, and chosen major(s and minors). 
All other analyses will be exploratory, largely to inform predictions in follow-up work once these scales meet basic criteria for reliability.

q18.value:
Some scale items are reverse coded.

*Views of the self and fields*

Item to be reversed	Scale
I think that when it comes to philosophy, the most important factors for success are motivation and sustained effort; raw ability is secondary.	Brilliance_Phil
I think that with the right amount of effort and dedication, many people could become a top scholar in philosophy. It’s mainly about hard work.	Brilliance_Phil
I think that when it comes to psychology, the most important factors for success are motivation and sustained effort; raw ability is secondary.	Brilliance_Psych
 I think that with the right amount of effort and dedication, many people could become a top scholar in psychology. It’s mainly about hard work.	Brilliance_Psych
Personally, I think that being a top scholar of psychology requires a special aptitude that just can’t be taught.	Brilliance_Psych
I tend to take longer to understand complicated ideas and theories than others.	Brilliance_Self
I need to study much harder than others in order to get good grades.	Brilliance_Self
I noticed early on that my mind seems to work less efficiently than the minds of others.	Brilliance_Self
 In group discussions, I don’t like to draw attention to myself.	Combativeness
If a debate or a theoretical discussion gets heated, I feel uncomfortable.	Combativeness
I like to work in a team with others rather than compete with them.	Combativeness
I challenge an idea only if this does not create conflict.	Combativeness
I tend to avoid confrontation.	Combativeness
I prefer working on my own.	Empathetic
Having work/a career that is interesting is my most important life goal, even above having a family.	Family prioritization
Having and raising children is not one of my life goals.	Family prioritization
No matter who you are, you can significantly change your intelligence level.	Mindset
You can change even your basic intelligence level considerably.	Mindset
The harder you work at something, the better you will be.	Mindset
No matter how much intelligence you have, you can always change it quite a bit.	Mindset
You can always substantially change how intelligent you are.	Mindset
Making enough money to be “well off” is not important to me.	Wealth prioritization
Building a name and reputation for myself through work/a career is not one of my life goals.	Status prioritization
I don’t see the point of abstract ideas that don’t help anyone in the real world.	Systematizing
I am not really interested in understanding how something works.	Systematizing

*Dichotomous choice between philosophy and psychology*

I think that with the right amount of effort and dedication, many people could become a top scholar in ______. It’s mainly about hard work.	Brilliance
I think that when it comes to ______, the most important factors for success are motivation and sustained effort; raw ability is secondary.	Brilliance
Working  in ______ would provide an interesting/exciting career.	Family prioritization
A career in ______ is well-suited for people who want satisfaction from work but nothing else.	Family prioritization
Making enough money to be “well off” is not a likely result of a career in  ______ .	Wealth prioritization
If you say that you study ______, people will probably make fun of you.	Status prioritization
When I meet new people, I think I might be judged negatively if I say I study ______.	Status prioritization

q19.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining statistical significance.

q20.value: We will exclude participants who fail the attention check (I would say that I am paying attention, as evidenced by my choosing the most negative option now) or failed to complete questions on gender and major. We will compare data across excluded and included participants to see whether they systematically vary

q21.value: Missing data will not be interpolated and participants with incomplete indices will not be included in analyses focused on those particular indices.

q22.value: Additional analyses examining how demographics, prototypes, view of the self, view of the field, attractiveness rating, interesting ranking, can be considered exploratory.

q23.value: Kyriazos, T. A. (2018). Applied psychometrics: sample size and sample power considerations in factor analysis (EFA, CFA) and SEM in general. Psychology, 9(08), 2207.

registration_responses.q1: Heather M. Maranges, Katharina Nieswandt, Kristen Dunfield, Ulf Hlobil, Maxine Iannuccilli
registration_responses.q2:
1)	In this pilot survey study, we expect that items of each a priori scale will load onto single factors (or a primary factor and reverse coded “artifactor” for scales with many reverse coded items) in exploratory factor analyses of each scale. See variable section for a priori scales.

We will also provide a tentative test of the following hypotheses, which have been forwarded as explanations for the gender imbalances across philosophy and psychology.

The Brilliance explanation is that philosophy, but not psychology, is viewed as requiring brilliance and that both men and women believe men have more innate brilliance than women. 

2)	Philosophy will be viewed as requiring more innate brilliance than psychology.
3)	Men will view themselves as having more innate brilliance than women.
4)	Women will hold stronger fixed (vs. growth) mindset beliefs compared to men.

The Combativeness explanation is that philosophy is compatible with or requires argumentativeness and men tend to be more argumentative than women. 

5)	Philosophy will be viewed as benefiting from a combative (vs. cooperative) nature, more than psychology.
6)	Men will view themselves as more combative (vs. cooperative) than women.

The Interest explanation is that women are more interested in people versus things—or are more empathizing versus systematizing—and vice versa, and psychology provides opportunities to empathize whereas philosophy provides opportunities to systematize.

7)	Men will view themselves as more systematizing (vs. empathizing), compared to women.

The Status vs. Family-Focus explanation is that women versus men value having a career that allows for having flexibility and a family and men value a career that garners social status; that psychology, versus philosophy, allows for flexibility for a family; and philosophy, versus psychology, garners social status. 

8)	Women will score higher on prioritization of a career that allows for a family, compared to men.
9)	Psychology will be viewed as better allowing for a family, compared to philosophy.
10)	Men will score higher on prioritization of a career that allows for social status, compared to women.
11)	Philosophy, compared to psychology, will be viewed as garnering more social status for women versus men.

We will also explore how desire for monetary wealth is associated with gender and perceptions of philosophy versus psychology. We tentatively expect no differences on average, but that preference for monetary wealth may lead to career choices outside of psychology and philosophy.

12)	Do men versus women prioritize monetary wealth from a career more?
13)	Do people perceive psychology versus philosophy as providing monetary wealth?
14)	Prioritization of monetary wealth from a career may be associated with preference for a career other than in philosophy, and perhaps other than psychology.

Finally,

15)	Factors for which there is a gender difference will predict academic major choice differences.
registration_responses.q3: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q4: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q7: Randomization. Participants are randomly assigned to one of the 8 vignette conditions, but all participants respond to the same survey.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any human observation of the data
registration_responses.q9: We have begun data collection but have not viewed data.
registration_responses.q11: Our target sample size is 350 participants. There will be 150 signup opportunities posted to the American university’s psychology department subject pool sign up system, to which all students in psychology classes have access. 350 students in philosophy and psychology at the Canadian university will be provided with the link to the online survey via class announcement online. Students have until April 15th to complete the survey.
registration_responses.q12: Based on prior exploratory piloting pretest data, we expect strong factor loadings on each of our a priori scales such that a minimum of 300 participants should allow us to establish a reliable factor structure via factor analyses (for review, see Kyriazos, 2018
registration_responses.q13: Data collection will be complete by April 15th at 5:00PM/17:00.
registration_responses.q18:
Some scale items are reverse coded.

*Views of the self and fields*

Item to be reversed	Scale
I think that when it comes to philosophy, the most important factors for success are motivation and sustained effort; raw ability is secondary.	Brilliance_Phil
I think that with the right amount of effort and dedication, many people could become a top scholar in philosophy. It’s mainly about hard work.	Brilliance_Phil
I think that when it comes to psychology, the most important factors for success are motivation and sustained effort; raw ability is secondary.	Brilliance_Psych
 I think that with the right amount of effort and dedication, many people could become a top scholar in psychology. It’s mainly about hard work.	Brilliance_Psych
Personally, I think that being a top scholar of psychology requires a special aptitude that just can’t be taught.	Brilliance_Psych
I tend to take longer to understand complicated ideas and theories than others.	Brilliance_Self
I need to study much harder than others in order to get good grades.	Brilliance_Self
I noticed early on that my mind seems to work less efficiently than the minds of others.	Brilliance_Self
 In group discussions, I don’t like to draw attention to myself.	Combativeness
If a debate or a theoretical discussion gets heated, I feel uncomfortable.	Combativeness
I like to work in a team with others rather than compete with them.	Combativeness
I challenge an idea only if this does not create conflict.	Combativeness
I tend to avoid confrontation.	Combativeness
I prefer working on my own.	Empathetic
Having work/a career that is interesting is my most important life goal, even above having a family.	Family prioritization
Having and raising children is not one of my life goals.	Family prioritization
No matter who you are, you can significantly change your intelligence level.	Mindset
You can change even your basic intelligence level considerably.	Mindset
The harder you work at something, the better you will be.	Mindset
No matter how much intelligence you have, you can always change it quite a bit.	Mindset
You can always substantially change how intelligent you are.	Mindset
Making enough money to be “well off” is not important to me.	Wealth prioritization
Building a name and reputation for myself through work/a career is not one of my life goals.	Status prioritization
I don’t see the point of abstract ideas that don’t help anyone in the real world.	Systematizing
I am not really interested in understanding how something works.	Systematizing

*Dichotomous choice between philosophy and psychology*

I think that with the right amount of effort and dedication, many people could become a top scholar in ______. It’s mainly about hard work.	Brilliance
I think that when it comes to ______, the most important factors for success are motivation and sustained effort; raw ability is secondary.	Brilliance
Working  in ______ would provide an interesting/exciting career.	Family prioritization
A career in ______ is well-suited for people who want satisfaction from work but nothing else.	Family prioritization
Making enough money to be “well off” is not a likely result of a career in  ______ .	Wealth prioritization
If you say that you study ______, people will probably make fun of you.	Status prioritization
When I meet new people, I think I might be judged negatively if I say I study ______.	Status prioritization
registration_responses.q19: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining statistical significance.
registration_responses.q20: We will exclude participants who fail the attention check (I would say that I am paying attention, as evidenced by my choosing the most negative option now) or failed to complete questions on gender and major. We will compare data across excluded and included participants to see whether they systematically vary
registration_responses.q21: Missing data will not be interpolated and participants with incomplete indices will not be included in analyses focused on those particular indices.
registration_responses.q22: Additional analyses examining how demographics, prototypes, view of the self, view of the field, attractiveness rating, interesting ranking, can be considered exploratory.
registration_responses.q23: Kyriazos, T. A. (2018). Applied psychometrics: sample size and sample power considerations in factor analysis (EFA, CFA) and SEM in general. Psychology, 9(08), 2207.
registration_responses.q6.question:
Survey, not randomized.
The only experimental aspect is to test whether people rate men and women’s attractiveness differentially depending on their field of study. Participants read a vignette about a recent college graduate, who is a man or woman, studied philosophy or psychology, and is brilliant or empathetic. Hence, this is a 2 (gender) x 2 (field) x 2 (characteristics) design.
registration_responses.q10.question: Participants will be students in psychology and philosophy classes at two large universities in Montreal, Quebec, CA and Tallahassee, Florida, USA completing an online survey. Psychology students will be compensated with credit toward introductory classes. Participants must be at least 18 years of age.
registration_responses.q14.question:
The only experimental aspect is to test whether people rate men and women’s attractiveness differentially depending on their field of study. Participants read a vignette about a recent college graduate, who is a man or woman, studied philosophy or psychology, and is brilliant or empathetic. Hence, this is a 2 (gender) x 2 (field) x 2 (characteristics) design.

See vignette attachment.

q14.uploader.file_name: Perceptions of attractiveness_Phil vs. Psych_Vignettes A-H.docx

registration_responses.q15.question:
See questionnaire document.
●	Age
●	Gender identity
●	Race/ethnicity
●	Family income
●	Major
●	Second major
●	Minor
●	Year of study
●	Grade point average upon admission to university
●	Expected grade in course
●	Psychologist stereotype
●	Philosopher stereotype
●	Questionnaire about self measuring: (see below for details on indices)
●	Questionnaire about psychology and philosophy measuring: (see below for details on indices)
●	Attractiveness rating of hypothetical target
●	Ranking of philosophical disciplines for personal interest
●	Ranking of psychological disciplines for personal interest
registration_responses.q16.question:
________Views of the self and fields________

______Brilliance, philosophy______
 If you want to succeed in philosophy, hard work alone just won’t cut it; you need to have an innate gift or talent.
Personally, I think that being a top scholar of philosophy requires a special aptitude that just can’t be taught.
I think that when it comes to philosophy, the most important factors for success are motivation and sustained effort; raw ability is secondary.
I think that with the right amount of effort and dedication, many people could become a top scholar in philosophy. It’s mainly about hard work.
It seems that people are just either good or bad at philosophy and there is not much that they can do to change that.

______Brilliance, psychology______
It seems that people are just either good or bad at psychology, and there is not much that they can do to change that.
I think that when it comes to psychology, the most important factors for success are motivation and sustained effort; raw ability is secondary.
Personally, I think that being a top scholar of psychology requires a special aptitude that just can’t be taught.
If you want to succeed in psychology, hard work alone just won’t cut it; you need to have an innate gift or talent.
 I think that with the right amount of effort and dedication, many people could become a top scholar in psychology. It’s mainly about hard work.

______Brilliance, self______
 I might have a world changing idea at some point.
People around me suspected from early on that I am intellectually gifted.
I tend to take longer to understand complicated ideas and theories than others.
I often have ideas that others didn’t think about.
I would say I am more intellectually gifted than average.
I pick up new concepts much faster than many classmates.
I need to study much harder than others in order to get good grades.
 I am good at coming up with ideas, and perhaps one day I will have an idea that changes the world.
Although I have never been properly tested, it seems likely that I have an higher than average IQ.
I noticed early on that my mind seems to work less efficiently than the minds of others.

______Combativeness______
I am not bothered by confrontational situations.
I thrive off heated discussions and debates.
I often get passionate in discussions.
If I know I’m right, then I will argue my point until others agree that I am right.
 In group discussions, I don’t like to draw attention to myself.
If a debate or a theoretical discussion gets heated, I feel uncomfortable.
In defending my ideas, I am sometimes perceived as insensitive.
I like to work in a team with others rather than compete with them.
I challenge an idea only if this does not create conflict.
I tend to avoid confrontation.

______Empathizing______
I am good at predicting how someone will feel.
I can tune into how someone else feels.
I can see myself in a job where I care for others, such as social worker or teacher.
I find it easy to put myself in somebody else’s shoes.
I prefer working on my own.
I often find social relations stressful.
I enjoy tasks where I help other people.

______Prioritizing family flexibility vs. interesting career______
Having work/a career that is interesting is my most important life goal, even above having a family.
I expect my family to give me more real satisfaction than anything else I do, including my work/career.
Having and raising children is not one of my life goals.

______Fixed vs. growth mindset______
Your intelligence is something about you that you can’t change very much.
To be honest, you can’t really change how much talent you have.
You can learn new things, but you can’t really change your basic intelligence.
No matter who you are, you can significantly change your intelligence level.
Your talent in an area is something about you that you can’t change very much.
You have a certain amount of intelligence, and you really can’t do much to change it.
You can change even your basic intelligence level considerably.
The harder you work at something, the better you will be.
No matter how much intelligence you have, you can always change it quite a bit.
You can always substantially change how intelligent you are.

______Prioritizing wealth from career______
I want to make a lot of money in my career.
I want a career that will allow me to afford to buy a nice house and other luxury items.
Making enough money to be “well off” is not important to me.

______Prioritizing social status from career______
I want a career that gets respect and admiration.
It is important to me to have a career that provides me with social status.
Building a name and reputation for myself through work/a career is not one of my life goals.

______Systematizing______
I don’t see the point of abstract ideas that don’t help anyone in the real world.
I like to think about abstract ideas.
I am more interested in theories than in working with people.
I am more interested in theories than in applications.
I’d prefer a job where I deal with technology to a job where I deal with human beings.
I am interested in the history of ideas.
I am not really interested in understanding how something works.
Logic puzzles keep me thinking until I find a solution.
I love to learn new abstract ideas.


________Dichotomous choice between philosophy and psychology________

______Brilliance______
If you want to succeed in ______, hard work alone just won’t cut it; you need to have an innate gift or talent.
I think that with the right amount of effort and dedication, many people could become a top scholar in ______. It’s mainly about hard work.
Personally, I think that being a top scholar of ______ requires a special aptitude that just can’t be taught.
I think that when it comes to ______, the most important factors for success are motivation and sustained effort; raw ability is secondary.
It seems that people are just either good or bad at ______ and there is not much they can do to change that.

______Prioritization of family flexibility vs. interesting career______
I think that a job in ______ would allow for flexible work hours.
Working  in ______ would provide an interesting/exciting career.
A career in ____ facilitates the work-life balance essential for having a family.
Working in ______ is well-suited for someone who views raising kids as the most important part of life.
A career in ______ is well-suited for people who want satisfaction from work but nothing else.

______Prioritization of wealth from career______
Working in  ______  would allow someone to buy a nice house and other luxury items.
_____ is well-suited to those who want to make a lot of money in their career.
Making enough money to be “well off” is not a likely result of a career in  ______ .

______Prioritization of social status from career______
Working in ______ would allow a person to build a name and reputation for him/herself.
A career in ______ gets respect and admiration.
Working in ______ provides social status.
If you say that you study ______, people will probably make fun of you.
Sometimes people say that they are interested in ______ to appear smart.
When I meet new people, I think I might be judged negatively if I say I study ______.
registration_responses.q17.question:
First, we will create our indices, test their reliability, and subject them to factor analyses. For the factor analyses, exploratory factor analyses using oblimin/oblique rotation with minimum eigenvalues of 2 will be conducted on a priori scale items. Items that do not load above .5 on or correlate above .4 with the primary factor (or a second reverse coded ‘artifactor’; see ) will be dropped, unless included in an original scale which we have adopted. We will adapt the measures for future use if after factor analyses, the scale alphas are below .75.
Second, we will examine the correlations among the indices, gender, and chosen major(s and minors). 
All other analyses will be exploratory, largely to inform predictions in follow-up work once these scales meet basic criteria for reliability.

summary.value:
Protocol for a scoping review on utilization of healthcare services by asthma patients in Sub Saharan African countries
The proposed scoping review will contribute towards the knowledge base on utilization of healthcare services particularly for people with the asthma condition. This will provide a better understanding of the determinants for utilization of health care services by asthma patients and ultimately contribute to improvement of  quality of care for people suffering from asthma. We will recommend solutions for asthma improving the utilization of healthcare services for asthma treatment. The results from the review will enlighten and guide health care practitioners and researchers on developing appropriate and feasible interventions to increase the utilization of healthcare services by asthma patients in resource constrained settings in Sub-Saharan African countries.

registration_responses.summary:
Protocol for a scoping review on utilization of healthcare services by asthma patients in Sub Saharan African countries
The proposed scoping review will contribute towards the knowledge base on utilization of healthcare services particularly for people with the asthma condition. This will provide a better understanding of the determinants for utilization of health care services by asthma patients and ultimately contribute to improvement of  quality of care for people suffering from asthma. We will recommend solutions for asthma improving the utilization of healthcare services for asthma treatment. The results from the review will enlighten and guide health care practitioners and researchers on developing appropriate and feasible interventions to increase the utilization of healthcare services by asthma patients in resource constrained settings in Sub-Saharan African countries.

attributes.title: Foreign Actors and Trust in Elections in Georgia

q1.value: Foreign Actors and Trust in Elections in Georgia

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Foreign electoral interventions are surprisingly common. They range from democracy-promoting interventions that attempt to level the electoral playing field to partisan interventions that seek to tilt the playing field in favor of a preferred candidate. Today, democracy-promoting international election observers monitor more than 80 percent of elections. And, great powers such as the United States and Russia have intervened in partisan ways in numerous elections since World War II, often doing so in ways that successfully swing elections for domestic allies. Although scholars have examined the effects of these interventions on outcomes such as electoral fraud and the vote count, a critical outcome has been overlooked in many studies: individual trust in elections. Likewise, research on trust in elections has focused mainly on domestic political explanations, ignoring the potential for foreign actors to affect electoral trust. This study seeks to understand why and under what conditions foreign actors influence local trust in elections through a case study of Georgia. The survey covered by this pre-registration document is a face-to-face pre-election survey conducted during two weeks prior to the 2018 presidential election in Georgia. We will employ a survey experiment with the following conditions: (a) a control group with no primes about foreign actors; (b) 3 treatment groups about international election monitors; and (c) 4 treatment groups about foreign meddling. The international election monitoring treatments provide information about the presence and activities of international election monitors. The international monitors are described as being: (a) capable of detecting fraud but biased in favor of a particular candidate; (b) not capable of detecting fraud but neutral towards all candidates; or (c) capable of detecting fraud and neutral towards all candidates. We are interested in comparing the treatments to each other as well as to the control of no treatment. Post-treatment questions probe which country or organization the respondent thought we were describing in the treatment. The foreign meddling treatments prime people through a question-order experiment in which individuals answer questions about whether they have heard rumors that foreign actors are attempting to influence the upcoming election, and how likely they think it is that foreign actors are attempting to influence the upcoming election. The actors described in the primes are: (a) the United States; (b) Russia; (c) European countries; and (d) Russia, as described in a report by an American organization. We are interested in comparing the treatments to each other, as a group to the control of no treatment, and individually to the control of no treatment. Given the format of the question-order experiment related to foreign meddling, we plan to analyze both all respondents who received the treatments and also those respondents who answered that it was at least “somewhat likely” or “not too likely” that the foreign actor in question was attempting to influence the upcoming election. Our core interest is in understanding how these experimental treatments affect individuals’ reported trust in the election, and that is what we focus on in this registration document. Further analyses may also explore how trust in election affects political behaviors, including through a follow-up survey conducted after the election. This registration document also explores several theoretically-relevant moderators as described below.

q16.value: We seek to test the following hypotheses about the direct effects of foreign actors: 1. People will have more trust in elections when they learn about the monitoring activities of election observers that they perceive as capable and unbiased. The logic behind this hypothesis, which we developed in prior work on this topic (Bush and Prather 2018), is that election observers can send a signal to the public about the electoral playing field, but only when they are perceived as being capable of detecting fraud and willing to do so (i.e., unbiased in their monitoring activities). Our emphasis on election observers that are perceived to be capable and unbiased matters since many different organizations serve as election observers around the same elections. 2. People will have less trust in elections when they think foreign meddling is likely. The logic here is similar in that foreign meddling sends a signal to the public about the fairness of the electoral playing field since meddlers are trying to tilt the playing field in favor of a particular candidate or party. We also seek to test the following hypotheses about how various factors moderate the effect of foreign actors: 1. Nationalism conditions the effect of foreign interventions on trust. We expect that any type of foreign intervention (but perhaps especially meddling) could spark a negative emotional response from highly nationalistic individuals, which affects how they update their trust in elections in response to foreign actors’ involvement. As such, nationalism may mute trust-enhancing information about election monitors and amplify trust-decreasing information about foreign meddling. 2. Feelings about specific foreign actors condition the effects of foreign interventions on trust. We hypothesize that when specific foreign countries or organizations inspire positive feelings, it can augment their positive effects on trust and mitigate or reverse their negative effects on trust. Similarly, when specific foreign countries or organizations inspire negative feelings, it can augment their negative effects on trust and mitigate or reverse their positive effects. 3. Vote choice conditions the effects of foreign interventions on trust. Building on our previous work on motivated reasoning and trust in elections (Bush and Prather 2017), we posit that election winners’ trust will be more positively influenced by trust-enhancing interventions, whereas election losers’ trust will be more negatively influenced by trust-decreasing interventions. However, the moderating effect of vote choice may be weaker in the pre-election environment since individuals are in a less emotional state as the results of the election are not yet known. 4. Strength of partisan or candidate attachment conditions the effects of foreign interventions on trust. We expect that people who have stronger attachments to parties or candidates will be more likely to have strong emotional reactions to winning or losing an election. Therefore, we expect that they will be more likely to display the conditional effects related to vote choice described above. However, the moderating effect of partisan or candidate attachment may be weaker in the pre-election environment since individuals are in a less emotional state as the results of the election are not yet known. We will also test a secondary hypothesis that trust-enhancing treatments will make people who previously reported trusting the election more certain about their trust and people who previously reported distrusting the election less certain, and vice versa for trust-decreasing treatments. In other words, it is possible that for some individuals we will not see their trust in the election change, but their certainty in their beliefs may respond to treatment.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested using the survey experiment described above. The key outcome measures in the study are as follows: 1. Main DV 1: Do you think that you will trust the results of the presidential election? (answer options: yes and no, followed by trust strongly, trust somewhat, trust a little, distrust a little, distrust somewhat, distrust strongly) 2. Main DV 2: Do you think it is likely that the results of the presidential election will reflect the will of the Georgian people? (answer options: yes and no, followed by very likely, somewhat likely, not too likely, not too unlikely, somewhat unlikely, very unlikely) 3. Secondary DV 1: How certain are you about your response to this question? (asked about DV 1; answer options: very certain, somewhat certain, not too certain, not certain at all. 4. Secondary DV 2: How certain are you about your response to this question? (asked about DV 2; answer options: very certain, somewhat certain, not too certain, not certain at all. The first two measures will be analyzed separately and in combination to capture electoral trust. When the dependent variable is binary, we will use logistic regression or difference of proportion tests, and when the dependent variable is ordered, we will use OLS or difference in means tests. We will use an alpha of 0.1, where the null hypothesis is that the mean of our outcome variable does not differ between experimental conditions. Demographic control variables will be included in some regression specifications; decisions about what to include will be informed by the results of balance tests. For a different operationalization, we can look at within-subject variation in reported trust, comparing responses to the same questions before and after the experimental treatments described above. We will use similar methods to test the hypothesis related to the secondary DVs. The key moderators in the study are as follows: 1. Nationalism: (1) When someone says something bad about the country of Georgia, how strongly do you feel it is as if they said something bad about you? (answer options: very strongly, somewhat strongly, not too strongly, not strongly at all); (2) How much do you feel that what happens to the country of Georgia in general will be your fate as well? (answer options: a lot, some, not too much, not at all); (3) If you are a citizen of Georgia, how much does being a Georgian citizen have to do with how you feel about yourself? (answer options: a lot, some, not too much, not at all); responses to these three questions may be combined into one measure of nationalism, depending on how correlated they are 2. Feelings about specific countries and organizations: Please tell me how favorably you feel about the following groups/countries in general? (a) the United States; (b) National Democratic Institute (NDI); (c) Russia; (d) Georgian civil society organizations; (e) European countries (answer options: very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable) 3. Vote choice: If voting: Who do you intend to vote for? If not voting: Although you do not intend to vote, who would you vote for if you were to vote? How likely do you think it is that [previous answer] will win the October 28 presidential election? (answer options: very likely, somewhat likely, not too likely, not likely at all.) 4. Strength of candidate attachment: Strong candidate attachment is indicated by people who support a particular candidate and plan to vote for that candidate, whereas weak candidate attachment is indicated by people who support a particular candidate but do not plan to go to the polls on Election Day. In the main analyses, we plan to create dichotomous indicators for each of these moderators; for the indicators that have four response options, we will combine the first two answer options and the second two answer options. Moderators will be interacted with the treatment variables using regression analyses of the sort described above. Because our moderating variables are observed rather than experimentally manipulated, we will control for other factors that could be related to the moderating variables and the outcome.

registration_responses.q1: Foreign Actors and Trust in Elections in Georgia
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

We expect that people who have stronger attachments to parties or candidates will be more likely to have strong emotional reactions to winning or losing an election. Therefore, we expect that they will be more likely to display the conditional effects related to vote choice described above. However, the moderating effect of partisan or candidate attachment may be weaker in the pre-election environment since individuals are in a less emotional state as the results of the election are not yet known. We will also test a secondary hypothesis that trust-enhancing treatments will make people who previously reported trusting the election more certain about their trust and people who previously reported distrusting the election less certain, and vice versa for trust-decreasing treatments. In other words, it is possible that for some individuals we will not see their trust in the election change, but their certainty in their beliefs may respond to treatment.
registration_responses.q17: The hypotheses will be tested using the survey experiment described above. The key outcome measures in the study are as follows: 1. Main DV 1: Do you think that you will trust the results of the presidential election? (answer options: yes and no, followed by trust strongly, trust somewhat, trust a little, distrust a little, distrust somewhat, distrust strongly) 2. Main DV 2: Do you think it is likely that the results of the presidential election will reflect the will of the Georgian people? (answer options: yes and no, followed by very likely, somewhat likely, not too likely, not too unlikely, somewhat unlikely, very unlikely) 3. Secondary DV 1: How certain are you about your response to this question? (asked about DV 1; answer options: very certain, somewhat certain, not too certain, not certain at all. 4. Secondary DV 2: How certain are you about your response to this question? (asked about DV 2; answer options: very certain, somewhat certain, not too certain, not certain at all. The first two measures will be analyzed separately and in combination to capture electoral trust. When the dependent variable is binary, we will use logistic regression or difference of proportion tests, and when the dependent variable is ordered, we will use OLS or difference in means tests. We will use an alpha of 0.1, where the null hypothesis is that the mean of our outcome variable does not differ between experimental conditions. Demographic control variables will be included in some regression specifications; decisions about what to include will be informed by the results of balance tests. For a different operationalization, we can look at within-subject variation in reported trust, comparing responses to the same questions before and after the experimental treatments described above. We will use similar methods to test the hypothesis related to the secondary DVs. The key moderators in the study are as follows: 1. Nationalism: (1) When someone says something bad about the country of Georgia, how strongly do you feel it is as if they said something bad about you? (answer options: very strongly, somewhat strongly, not too strongly, not strongly at all); (2) How much do you feel that what happens to the country of Georgia in general will be your fate as well? (answer options: a lot, some, not too much, not at all); (3) If you are a citizen of Georgia, how much does being a Georgian citizen have to do with how you feel about yourself? (answer options: a lot, some, not too much, not at all); responses to these three questions may be combined into one measure of nationalism, depending on how correlated they are 2. Feelings about specific countries and organizations: Please tell me how favorably you feel about the following groups/countries in general? (a) the United States; (b) National Democratic Institute (NDI); (c) Russia; (d) Georgian civil society organizations; (e) European countries (answer options: very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, very unfavorable) 3. Vote choice: If voting: Who do you intend to vote for? If not voting: Although you do not intend to vote, who would you vote for if you were to vote? How likely do you think it is that [previous answer] will win the October 28 presidential election? (answer options: very likely, somewhat likely, not too likely, not likely at all.) 4. Strength of candidate attachment: Strong candidate attachment is indicated by people who support a particular candidate and plan to vote for that candidate, whereas weak candidate attachment is indicated by people who support a particular candidate but do not plan to go to the polls on Election Day. In the main analyses, we plan to create dichotomous indicators for each of these moderators; for the indicators that have four response options, we will combine the first two answer options and the second two answer options. Moderators will be interacted with the treatment variables using regression analyses of the sort described above. Because our moderating variables are observed rather than experimentally manipulated, we will control for other factors that could be related to the moderating variables and the outcome.

attributes.title: IHO
attributes.description: Preregistration for the Intellectual Humility and Overconfidence study.

summary.value: This is the preregistration that contains project overview, hypotheses, method, and planned analysis for the Intellectual Humility and Overconfidence study.

registration_responses.summary: This is the preregistration that contains project overview, hypotheses, method, and planned analysis for the Intellectual Humility and Overconfidence study.

attributes.title: Grit, Conscientiousness, and Academic Involvement at Midwestern State University
attributes.description: Previous research shows that conscientiousness (being organized and thoughtful) is a personality predictor of academic success. We are investigating how the personality trait Grit relates to academic involvement, engagement, and self-efficacy in students. Grit is defined as the propensity to sustain the interest and effort needed to achieve long-term goals (e.g. passion + perseverance). We predict that Grit will be seen more in students who are highly involved on campus. These involved students will also show high academic self-efficacy, which could indicate grit is a moderating factor in the relationship between academic self-efficacy and campus engagement. Conversely, we predict that conscientiousness will uniquely predict academic success “on paper” (i.e. GPA) but not necessarily campus engagement. Conscientiousness should moderate the relationship between academic self-efficacy and GPA.

q2.value:
Hypothesis 1: Grit will uniquely predict engagement in extra-curricular activities.
Hypothesis 2: Conscientiousness will uniquely predict GPA
Hypothesis 3: Grit and conscientiousness will predict academic engagement
Hypothesis 4: Academic self-efficacy (ASE) will moderate the relationship between grit and extracurricular activities. ASE will moderate the relationship between conscientiousness and GPA. ASE will moderate the relationship between conscientiousness and academic engagement. And, ASE will moderate the relationship between grit and academic engagement.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This project is a correlational study that examines academic involvement, academic engagement, grit, conscientiousness, and academic self-efficacy. The statistical process controls for demographics such as age, gender, etc.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data will be collected electronically via survey. Subjects will be forced to accept an informed consent waiver before the survey will allow them to input data. The survey is split into six blocks, each one measuring one trait or their demographics.

q11.value: The sample size goal is to get 300 students from Midwestern State University. 200 of them should be high-achievers or highly involved in athletics, Greek Life, or academic honors societies, and 100 should be average students.

question.value: Measured variables will include Grit, Big Five Personality (Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, Neuroticism), Academic Engagement, and General Self-Efficacy.
Statistical methods will consist of correlational and regressional calculations to control for demographic data and focus on the measured variables.

registration_responses.q2:
Hypothesis 1: Grit will uniquely predict engagement in extra-curricular activities.
Hypothesis 2: Conscientiousness will uniquely predict GPA
Hypothesis 3: Grit and conscientiousness will predict academic engagement
Hypothesis 4: Academic self-efficacy (ASE) will moderate the relationship between grit and extracurricular activities. ASE will moderate the relationship between conscientiousness and GPA. ASE will moderate the relationship between conscientiousness and academic engagement. And, ASE will moderate the relationship between grit and academic engagement.
